newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft proposes new Internet standards.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft proposes new Internet standards.

text.p: Microsoft Corp, moving to make access to the Internet more like watching television, said Wednesday it proposed a set of software technologies to the World Wide Web's standard-setting body.
The technology would let Internet news organisations and entertainment sites broadcast their programmes to specific computer users interested in getting them.

The software giant's move would put pressure on Netscape Communications Corp., which is leading a loosely knit group of software companies backing a rival standard for broadcasting content through the Internet.

Microsoft said the technology, called channel definition format, will be a part of the next version of its Internet Explorer browser, the programme that lets computer users access the Web and other sections of the Internet.
Microsoft has a history of proposing its own set of software standards to boost its products in new markets, such as databases.
The company also said America Online Inc., the world's biggest online service, has agreed to use the standards to broadcast Internet programmes to its 8 million subscribers.
PointCast Inc., a closely held broadcaster of news through the Internet, also said it agreed to use Microsoft's software standards.
Microsoft's set of proposed standards would compete against technologies from several start-ups such as Marimba Inc.
